articles.author: Ken Kremer
articles.summary:
KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, FL - NASA Administrator Charles Bolden announced that
Boeing and SpaceX have won the high stakes and history making NASA competition
to build the first ever private ‘space taxis’ to launch American astronauts to
the International Space Station (ISS) and restore America’s capability to
launch our crews from American soil for the […]
articles.title: Boeing and SpaceX Win NASA’s ‘Space Taxi’ Contracts for Space Station Flights (Universe Today)

articles.author: Guardian: Gregor Robertson
articles.summary:
Guardian: Around the world, cities are taking the lead on addressing the
challenge of climate change. While senior governments stall, urban leaders are
responding to the urgent need to make our cities more resilient as climate
change impacts intensify. In Vancouver, we are aggressively pursuing our goal
to be the greenest city in the world by 2020. It’s a bold goal, but in working
toward it, we are protecting our environment and growing our economy. The
successful cities of the future will be those making...
articles.title: Canada: Cities can lead on climate change to build a resilient future (climateark)

articles.summary:
When an endangered species stops breeding, you know its days are probably
numbered. In China the countdown has apparently begun for the critically
endangered Chinese sturgeon (Acipenser sinensis).


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Chinese Sturgeon Give Up, Stop Breeding in Polluted Yangtze River (Scientific American)

articles.summary:
These are adult marine (top) and freshwater (bottom) threespine sticklebacks
(_Gasterosteus aculeatus_) stained with a red dye that labels calcified bone.
Sticklebacks, the roaches of the fish world, are the ideal animal in which to
study the genes that control body shape. They've moved from the ocean into
tens of thousands of freshwater streams and lakes around the world, each time
changing their skeleton to adapt to the new environment.
articles.title: Counting fish teeth reveals regulatory DNA changes behind rapid evolution, adaptation (Biologynews)

articles.summary:
Dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase deficiency and its relationship with gene DLD
have been added to Genetics Home Reference. Web links to MedlinePlus, patient
support web sites, Gene Reviews, Genetic Testing Registry, ClinicalTrials.gov,
and OMIM are included.
articles.title: dihydrolipoamide dehydrogenase deficiency (US NLM)

articles.author: Jennifer Viegas
articles.summary:
Chimps and humans share violent tendencies, with a new study showing that the
evolutionary roots of warfare exist in our primate ancestry.
articles.title: Killer Chimps Reveal Why Violence Persists (Discovery)

articles.author: By JAMES GORMAN
articles.summary:
A new survey suggests that violence is a natural part of chimp behavior and
not the result of actions by humans that push the animals to lethal attacks.
articles.title: Lethal Violence in Chimps Occurs Naturally, Study Suggests (New York Times)

articles.summary:

several proven tactical ideas for improving the world, says an influential
international sustainable development networking organization.

(Reuters) - U.S. government researchers working with divers and sonar
equipment have located the wrecks of what they dubbed "forgotten ghost ships"
in waters just outside San Francisco's Golden Gate strait.

articles.summary:
Researchers in the US have figured out how to control the surface tension of
liquid metals, to make new electronic circuits, antennas, and yes, maybe even
T-1000 shape-shifting robot assassins.
articles.title: Scientists move liquid metals into humanoid shapes (and other more useful things) (Science Alert)

(Reuters) - A simple urine test for the virus that causes cervical cancer
could offer a less invasive and more acceptable alternative to the
conventional cervical smear test, researchers said on Tuesday. In a study
comparing the accuracy of urine … Read More
articles.title: Urine Test for Cervical Cancer Virus Offers Alternative to Smear (bioethicscom)
